summary: Members of the Armed Peasants Group (ACA), a former faction of the Paraguayan People's Army (EPP), became involved in a firefight with security forces inHorqueta, Concepcion department on 7 January. Two ACA members died in the exchange and five fled.

summary:
Lashkar-e-Jhangvi militants detonated two large bombs in central Quetta, killing 81 civilians and wounding 121 others.
According to local police reports the attack targeted a large pool and snooker gaming hall in the basement of a four-storey building. A man carrying a plastic bag entered the pool hall and detonated the bomb that he was carrying. Fifteen minutes later a larger bomb, placed in a car parked at the entrance to the building, was detonated remotely. Rescue service officials say the second bomb caused the majority of the deaths and injuries.
In addition to the human deaths caused by the attack, the explosions caused a severe blackout in the Alamdar area, leaving the district without electricity for several hours.
Lashkar-e-Jhangvi spokesmen claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that the Hazara community that is the predominant group in the area was the intended target. Hazaras in Balochistan have been the targets of several attacks in the past decade.
area: Alamdar Road area, Quetta city, Balochistan province
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
In Kirkuk, a bomb killed two when it exploded as police attempted to defuse it.
The attack was part of a series of coordinated attacks across central and eastern Iraq which killed at least 13 people and wounded more than 40 others. Militants carried out bombings and shootings in Hilla, Mussayib and Kirkuk.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks immediately, however the Al-Qaeda affiliated group Islamic State of Iraq has previously claimed responsibility for large-scale coordinated attacks in the country.

summary:
A twin suicide bomb attack killed 6 people and injured several others in Jalalabad airbase.
According to local military reports two trucks laden with explosives were driven at the main gates of the airbase, one exploding directly in contact with the gates, while the other detonated shortly before it reached its target. Taliban gunmen then assaulted the base with small-arms fire, triggering a gun battle that lasted two hours.
Four of the victims were soldiers in the Afghan National Army (ANA) and two others were civilian medical students from a private Afghan medical school. The number of injuries that the attack caused remains unclear. A NATO spokesman stated that nine militants took part in the assault, three of whom died in the initial explosions. NATO troops at the base called in air support in the form of attack helicopters, killing a further six militants.
Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid claimed responsibility for the attack

summary:
On November 1, gunmen shot dead David Black, a Northern Ireland prison officer, on the M1 motorway in County Armagh.
A car drove up beside Black's car and gunmen fired a number of shots. Black's car veered into a ditch and he died at the scene.
The victim worked at Maghaberry top security prison - a jail in which violent republican protests are common. Mr. Black was the first prison officer murdered in Northern Ireland in almost 20 years. He was also a member of the Protestant Orange Order.

summary:

The large bomb blast occurred inAshrafiyeh neighbourhood and killed Wissam al-Hassan, intelligence chief for Lebenon's Internal Security Forces, along with seven others. The bomb exploded in a populated area of the Christian neighbourhood, reportedly injuring up to 70 nearby civilians.
The American Univeristy of Science and Techonolgy is also located in the area.
Local media reported that the bombing was a clear sign that Syria's civil war was spilling over into Lebanon. Several local authorities commented on Syrian involvement in the blast.
The US Embassy in Beirut issued a security message following the blast, warning of travel disruptions and street closures in the city caused by locals who protested the blast.
It was the largest blast in Beirut since a bombing in 2008 that wounded 86 people.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
A Bangladeshi nationalattempted to detonate a van full of what he thought were explosives outside the USFederal Reserve Bank in downtown Manhattan, but failed and was arrested by the FBI.
The 21 year old male reportedly drove the van intoManhattan, accompanied by an undercover FBI agent and what he believed was a 1,000lb bomb. The fake explosives were sold to the man via Facebook by FBI agents posing as al-Qaeda leaders. He positioned the van outside the bank and attempted to detonate the device from a nearby hotel. He failed and was subsequently arrested.
The man arrived in the US months early on a student visa. He allegedly discussed a variety of targets with undercover agents, including the New York Stock Exchange.
While the man claimed to be inspired by al-Qaeda, his links to the terrorist group seem limited,according to authorities.
No terrorist group claimed responsibility or links to the incident.

summary:

The claim was corroborated by the press secretary of Vice President Karim Khalili, who was injured in the leg during the attack. Local government sources, however, stated that the Vice President was not present.
Afghan National Police units returned fire, engaging the Taliban militants for about half an hour. It remains unclear whether or not any of the militants were wounded or killed in the attack.
After the attack the convoy continued its journey to Kabl.

The armed militants forcibly entered a meeting of the council in Malkangiri district and abducted three of its officers, removing them to a nearby forest.
The militants then released the three men unharmed, along with a nine-point charter of demands to the regional government. The demands included the construction of an 8 km irrigation canal and the withdrawal of security forces from the region.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip fired a shoulder launched Strela SA7 missile at an Isreali Air Force (IAF) aircraft. The missile missed its target.
The attack represents the first time that such advanced weaponry has been used against an aerial target over Gaza. Strela missiles were used against an Israeli airliner over Mombasa in 2002 and were also used in an attack in Sinai in 2011.
Intelligence reports suggest that a number of these lightweight, heat-seeking weapons have found their way to Hamas militants from Libya in recent months.
The IAF has not officially commented on the attack.

summary:
Government security forces uncovered and foiled a plot to bomb a military base in the southern province of Lahij.
Two Al-Qaeda militants reportedly drove a truck into the air base, forcing their way through the entry checkpoint. Yemeni security troops guarding the base managed to stop the militants before they could detonate their bombs. It remains unclear whether or not the two assailants were killed in the attack.
The truck was laden with explosives and was intended to target military personnel, particularly US military troops stationed at the base.
The United States has supported Yemeni government operations against Al-Qaeda cells in the country, predominantly using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) or "Drones" to surgically target suspected Al-Qaeda operatives, particularly leaders of the terrorist group. Drone operations have been particularly successful in recent months, reportedly eliminating numerous important Al-Qaeda leaders.
Al-Qaeda did not claim the failed attack, although the group is highly active in the country.
area: Al-Anad military air base, Lahij province
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

A spokesman for the country's military stated that troops had been sent to the airstrip to defend other hardware. Private security usually guard the airstrip.
The attack coincided with the visit of U.S. Defence Secretary Leon Panetta to the country, although there does not seem to be any link between his visit and the attack.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although the Marxist group Shining Path have been highly active in the area in the past.

summary:

The Front's communique claimed that each of these sites was specifically chosen due to its frequent use by government troops and officials.

summary:
Unidentified armed gunmen attacked the Tasfirat prison in Tikrit, Salah ad-Din governorate, killing at least 12 prison guards and freeing at least 80 prisoners.
The attack was initiated by a suicide car bomb blast at the gates of the prison, before militants entered the prison. The ensuing clashes lasted several hours before security personnel were able to re-take the prison.
Several of the escaped inmates were believed to be Al-Qaeda militants, and during the attack, information about informants was believed to have been stolen, whilst prisoner personnel records destroyed. Weapons were also seized by the escaping inmates.
No group claimed responsibility, but prisons have been targeted in coordinated attacks in the past. A resurgent Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), an Al-Qaeda affiliate, had announced their return to activity and had stated that they intended to aid their members in prison.
source_urls: BBC News; Xinhua; Al Arabiya; Ap; AFP; Reuters;

summary:
Two suicide car bomb blasts targeted the army headquarters in Damascus. Four guards were reported killed and 14 more wounded, including civilians.
The attack occurred first thing in the morning, when the main building in the compound was hit and set on fire. Reports suggested a white van drove up and stopped on the roadside before the first blast occurred. The second explosion followed approximately 10 minutes later the second explosion occurred inside the compound. The General Staff Command Building had been targeted by the attack and was seen ablaze following the explosions.
In the wake of the attack, a two-hour gunfight was reported as soldiers hunted down the militants.
The Free Syrian Army, who have coalesced as the principle opposition force to the Syrian government claimed responsibility for the attack. However, a group called Tajamo Ansar al-Islam also claimed responsibility shortly after. And in an internet posting, the Al-Nusra Front also claimed responsibility for the attack. The Al-Nusra Front have carried out several other terrorist attacks since the Syrian uprising began.
source_urls: BBC, The Guardian, Reuters; FT; Israel National News;
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jabhat al-Nusra (JaN/Al-Nusra Front), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on the Egypt-Israeli border in the Sinai, killing one Israeli soldier and wounding a second.
The attack occurred close to Har Harif, where the border fence is still under construction.
The gunmen had approached from the Sinai area and opened fire on the border at a distance. IDF troops had been stationed at the area to oversee ongoing construction work, and the troops returned fire, killing three militants. One Israeli soldier was wounded when the gunfire caused an explosive belt worn by one militant to detonate.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Since the fall of former President Mubarak, security in the Sinai region has deteriorated. The quantity and quality of weapons recovered in the latest incident led the IDF to declare that the gunmen had been attempting a serious attack if they had successfully crossed the border.

summary: Two viable bombs were defused by Army officers before they could detonate at Derry City Council offices in Derry/Londonderry.  A pipe bomb had been hidden inside a holdall bag left on the office grounds, whilst a second bomb on a timer had been attached to a bicycle tired to railings at the rear of the office building. It was thought that the bicycle bomb had been intended to target security personnel who arrived to deal with the pipe bomb in the holdall.  Dissident Republicans were blamed for the attempt, but made no comment and did not claim responsibility for the attack. The attempt is concerning as Derry will be the 2013 UK City of Culture.

Two bombers targeted a cafe in the area frequented by journalists and government officials. It was located less than a mile from the Presidential Palace. One opened fire on the crowd before detonating his explosives, the other detonated his in a separate are of the cafe.
It was the second significant attack in the city since the election of the new President Mohamoud on 10 September. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but Al-Shabaab militants have continued to be active despite a government crackdown, and had previously threatened to continue targeting the new government.

summary:

The attack had occurred during the morning rush hour in the city, and came a week after a spree of attacks in the city, and across the country, killed and wounded over a hundred people.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) had previously issued a statement, stating their intended resurgence of activity across the country.

summary:
At least 19 Taliban militants attacked Camp Bastion NATO military base in Helmand province, killing two US Marines. Several others were wounded, and material damage was cause to the base.
The militants attacked with small arms, RPGs and suicide IED vests the American Camp Leatherneck section of the base. Aircraft and buildings along the flight line were damaged in the attack. Several British troops were wounded when some of the militants detonated their explosive vests. All bar one militant was killed in the return fire, and the remaining one was wounded and arrested. The attack lasted over five hours.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, however, there were conflicting reports that the attack had been motivated by revenge for an anti-Islamic film trailer that had surfaced online, as well as or also motivated by the intention to target Britain's Prince Harry who is currently deployed with the Army to Bastion.
It raises serious questions about the security capabilities of the area, as the base is heavily fortified and guarded.
source_urls: Xinhua; The Telegraph; Voice of America; BBC News; The Guardian
area: Camp Bastion, Lashkar Gah district, Helmand province

summary:

summary:

According to local security forces the attack was an attempted assassination of the recently elected Somali president, Hassan Sheikh Mohamud, at a hotel where he was holding a press conference with the Kenyan foreign minister.
Reports indicate that the first blast occurred outside the main gate of the building, and that gunfire erupted immediately afterwards. The second blast occurred soon after. One Ugandan soldier from the African Union force was killed, along with four Somali troops. Two civilians were also injured. 
According to a local police spokesperson all the people inside the hotel are safe and unharmed.
The Al-Shabaab militia, which has been highly active in the country and opposed Mr. Mohamud's election, claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary: An explosion occurred outside a police station in Sultangazi, a working class residential district in northwest Istanbul. At least one police officer died and three others were injured in the attack.  Police confirmed that the attack was a suicide bombing and claimed that the attacker was a member of the outlawed Revolutionary Peoples Liberation Party-Front (DHKP/C).  Though suicide bombings are most frequently associated with jihadist groups, Kurdish separatists and left-wing groups have carried out suicide bombings in Istanbul in the past. The most notable such attack took place on 31 October 2010, when a Kurdish militant detonated his explosive vest near a police patrol on Taksim Square, wounding 32 people.  The DHKP/C claimed responsibility for the attack in a post on the group's website, but the claim was not verified.

summary:
Several dozen gunmen attacked the US Consulate in the Western Fuwayhat area of Benghazi. Four American nationals including the US Ambassador to Libya, J. Christopher Stevens were killed in the attack. At least ten people were wounded, two of them also American nationals.
At around 2200hrs on 11 September, gunmen opened fire on the Consulate building, before entering the premises and setting the building alight. The fighting lasted until 0230hrs. Ambassador Stevens and IT officer Sean Smith died from smoke inhalation.
A nearby CIA compound was also attacked with mortar fire at around 0400hrs on 12 September. Two security agents died and another ten were injured.
The attack had initially been reported as an escalation by protesters, angry over an anti-Islamic film trailer that insulted the Prophet Muhammed. However, the attack bore signs of being pre-planned, after armed men used RPGs as well as guns to fire upon the building.
No group has claimed responsibility, but suggestions have been made that it could have been ordered by Ayman al-Zawahiri as a revenge attack for a drone strike earlier in the year. The Imprisoned Omar Rahman Brigades, with links to Ansar al-Sharia, who carried out attacks against both the Consulate and the Red Cross offices in the city earlier in the year were also speculated to have been involved.
On 27 September, US Defense Secretary Panetta confirmed that the US viewed the incident as a terrorist attack. Investigations revealed that Ansar al-Sharia played a significant role in the attack.
source_urls: The Guardian; The Telegraph; BBC News; Reuters; Xinhua
area: Western Fuwayhat area, Benghazi city, Cyrenaica region
attributions: perpetrator_name: Ansar al-Sharia Libya (ASL), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: True,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomb blast in the Sharsh Darak neighbourhood of Kabul killed at least six people including children, and wounded four more.
The blast occurred by both the ISAF headquarters and US Embassy, which were located in that neighbourhood. The bomber drove on a motorbike to the entrance of Camp Eggers, the base for coalition personnel who train Afghan recruits, before detonating his explosive vest.
The attack occurred as the 11th anniversary of the death of the resistance leader Ahmad Shah Masoud was being marked.
The Taliban claimed responsibility, saying they had targeted the base of the CIA agency where Afghans were recruited for spying. The ability for the attack to have been carried out in an area which would have had elevated levels of security is of concern, and will again raise doubts about the provision of security post-2014, the projected withdrawal date for foreign troops in the country.
source_urls: Xinhua; Reuters; BBC News; Al Jazeera;

attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
One of four coordinated attacks across Kirkuk city wounded at least four police officers. The explosions in the Musali neighbourhood occurred as Friday prayers were concluding.
The second of the four attacks occurred at the Imam Ali husseiniyah, a Shia place of worship. Two roadside devices detonated, one wounding four police officers attempting to defuse it.
It followed an initial car bomb blast at the Khezal al Tamimi in the Domiz area of the city.
No responsibility for the attack was claimed. Sectarian violence has begun to escalate in the country again, and the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), t he local faction of Al-Qaeda in the country recently re-emerged, stating a return to their terrorist campaign.

summary:
One of four coordinated attacks across Kirkuk city killed at least five people and wounded at least 30 more. The explosions in the Domiz neighbourhood occurred as Friday prayers were concluding.
The third of the four attacks occurred at the Al Mustafa husseiniyah, a Shia place of worship. Two car and a roadside bomb detonated, after worshippers had been informed of the first blast of the day and were attempting to leave the prayer hall. Some reports claimed that the second car bomb detonated as security personnel responded to the scene. Two children were amongst the fatalities, and many cars in the vicinity were destroyed.
It followed an initial car bomb blast at the Khezal al Tamimi, also in the Domiz area of the city, and a second in the Musali area.
No responsibility for the attack was claimed. Sectarian violence has begun to escalate in the country again, and the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), the local faction of Al-Qaeda in the country recently re-emerged, stating a return to their terrorist campaign.

summary:
Unidentified militants attacked a NATO supply convoy in the Dasht area of Mastung district. Two vehicles were set alight in the attack. No other casualties were incurred in the attack.
The two logistics vehicles for ISAF were en route from Karachi when the attack occurred on the Quetta-Sibi Road. Gunmen on a motorbike opened fire at the trucks - there was an unverified report that the driver and cleaner had been wounded by the bullets, but no further information was available.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Taliban militants frequent target logistics convoys, as a means of disrupting the ISAF campaign in Afghanistan. However, Balochistan is also facing a separatist insurgency of its own, and the attack may have been carried out by separatist militants.

summary:

Both the governor and the Shinwari tribe who inhabit the area were long-standing opponents of the Taliban.
The Taliban denied involvement in the attack, saying it was probably the result of personal or4 tribal enmity.

summary:
A fake explosive device was concealed on a bridge in tambon Su-Ngai Padi, Narathiwat province. The device was removed by police.
The device, a cardboard box with wires sticking out, was discovered by Ban Joh Wa in the Su-Ngai Padi area, half a kilometer from a police Border Patrol station.
The discovery came in three days after at least 60 explosive devices, some viable others fake, were found across the four southern Thai provinces. A second, real explosive was also discovered the same day in a separate district. No responsibility for the fake explosive was claimed.

summary:
A suicide car bomb killed at least three people close to the US consulate in Peshawar, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. At least 19 people, including four policemen, were wounded in the blast.
The bomber drove an explosives-filled car into a convoy that had exited from the consulate in the University Town area of the city. The convoy comprised two consulate vehicles escorted by three police cars. The UN High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) is also located in the same area. The US consulate refuted claims that American consulate staff were among the fatalities, though two American nationals were wounded.
At least 110 kg of explosives were used in the blast, leaving a five by eight foot crater in the middle of the road. Part of the UNHCR building was also damaged, and several vehicles in the vicinity destroyed.
Dawn News reported that the consulate had received threats two days prior, and had been on high alert before the attack occurred.
No group claimed responsibility, but the TTP and affiliated groups are active in the region and have frequently carried out attacks in the area in the past.
targets: Civilians/General Public; Government/Political ; Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces

summary:
Two Taliban suicide bombings exploded themselves, killing 14 and injuring 69 othersSayidabad district in Wardak province.
The incident occurred 30 km west of Kabul at approximately 0615hrs near the gate of the district headquarters and next to the police department. Several shops and houses in the area were also damaged.
Eight civilians, four policemen and the two bombers were killed in the blasts. According to eye witnesses, the second bomb went off as people gathered to rescue the victims from the first blast.
ISAF stated that the attack had been carried out by the Haqqani faction. The Taliban claimed the attack via phone call to the local media the same day.

summary:
A bomb blast triggered a fire in a department store in theMuangNarathiwat neighbourhood.Firemen took several hours to control the blaze.
The device had been concealed by flammable items causing the fire to rapidly spread. 5kg of explosives were thought to have been attached to fuel in order to facilitate the spread of the fire. The blaze destroyed the department store and burnt nearby houses. It was the 18th time the chain had been targeted by bombings and arson since it opened in 2004.
The store had been located in the so-called "safe zone", an area of heightened security.
No responsibility for the attack was claimed.
source_urls: The Nation; Pattaya Daily; Bangkok Post
area: Narathiwat city, Muang Narathiwat district, Narathiwat province

attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Explosive objects were strung along the main motorway linking Pattani and Songkhla province in Thailand, though they failed to cause harm or damage.
The devices, some viable explosives, others fakes, were found strung from trees and electricity poles on the motorway between Khok Pho district, Pattani, and Thepha district, Songkhla. They disrupted traffic as police attended to the devices. Several had been concealed by schools, forcing the schools to close for the day.
Fake devices were also found at 15 locations across three districts of Songkhla. In both provinces, as in Yala and Narathiwat, tyres and Thai flags were also burnt, and spikes strewn over roads.
The spree occurred as Malaysians across the border celebrated Independence Day. It was not known why Malaysian flags were flown at many of the sites of the explosives. No group claimed responsibility for the spree of devices.
connected_attacks: connected_incident_id:21408:name:Thailand | Bombing | Yaha district; connected_incident_id:21407:name:Thailand | Explosive projectile | Rangae district
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A spate of threatening devices were littered across Yala province. No casualties were incurred but it was part of a spree of incidents that occurred across the southern Thai provinces that day.
Threatening messages taunting local authorities were left at three locations in Yaha district, as were suspected explosive devices, some viable, others fakes. Similar devices were also found in Bangnang Sata and Yala districts. Police disarmed the viable explosive devices without injury.
There were also reports of burning tyres and spikes scattered on roads, damaging vehicles.
No responsibility for the spree was claimed, though Malaysian flags were raised in several of the areas. It was not known why the flags appeared as militants have not previously sough unification with Malaysia.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A grenade was thrown at the office of a Provincial Electricity Authority in Rangae district, causing only material damage.
It was the latest incident in a string of incidents that day. Explosive devices, both real and fakes, were found at 43 locations across the 12 districts of Narathiwat. Four of those had detonated wounding at least five security officers.
Press reports claimed similiar devices, both viable and fakes, were also found across Yala, Pattani and Songkhla provinces. It was thought around 60 such devices had been planted.
No responsibility for the spree was claimed, but it occurred as Malaysians across the border celebrated their Independence Day, and Malaysian flags were raised across the southern Thai provinces to accompany the attacks.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Two bomb blasts in Sadr City, Baghdad killed at least three people and wounded eight more. The explosions targeted the Friday lunchtime prayer session.
The explosions occurred in the principally Shia area of the city, close to the offices of a Shia cleric. One device detonated beside the pulpit of the outdoor mosque, mid-way through the service. The second exploded seconds later, where it had been concealed in the ground in the midst of the congregation.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but the Al-Qaeda affiliate Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) recently announced its planned return to power, and they have targeted Shia areas in the past.

summary:

The militants attacked the building, located in the Al-Tawahi neighbourhood and next to the state television office, from two sides. They were reported to have driven to the entrance by the TV office, blowing up the military guard before launching an armed attack with rifles and grenades. Simultaneously, a car bomb detonated on the other side of the intelligence building, causing part of it to collapse.
AQAP made no comment on the attack. Despite the government's push to eliminate the militant presence from the southern states AQAP remains active, and since the inauguration of President Hadi, have carried out several mass-casualty attacks.

summary:
Multiple bomb blasts targeting security forces injured a police officer.
According to local media Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), who are highly operative in the area, are believed to be responsible for the attacks. One bomb, planted near a police station in the town, seems to have been remotely detonated. At about the same time a series of mines detonated when a security convoy passed over them, triggering a fire fight between government forces and armed militants. No casualties were reported on either side.
In a linked attack on a police checkpoint in the town, which occurred shortly after the mine blasts, suspected PKK militants attacked security personnel at their post from three sides. No casualties were reported on either side.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although PKK forces have been fighting government troops since 1984, calling for an independent Kurdish state in the area. Since the beginning of the conflict more than 40,000 people have been killed, both civilian and combatant.

summary:
A car bomb explosion in central Damascus wounded three people.The incident happened near Shukri Qubaitly Street, Abu Roumaneh district, next to a hotel when the UN mission in Syria is based. International news reports suggest none of the UN staff were hurt.
Syrian state TV says the device was attached to a fuel tanker. It is unclear how the bomb was attached' to the petrol tanker, as the Syrian media describes.
Based on other attacks in Syria, it is possible the device was a sticky bomb' - an explosive device attached by magnet or adhesive to a target. Such devices are relatively cheap, use small amounts of explosives and more precise than roadside bombs. They are also easier to get into an area that may have searches on vehicles. A remote signal or a timer also means that the bombers can attach a device to a vehicle at a distance from the point of detonation.  Such an approach would likely be an effective way of breaching security as guards may have presumed it was a delivery for the hotel - this is particularly plausible given ongoing power and fuel shortages in the country.
There have been previous instances where such devices have been used in Syria, including in central Damascus; on 28 June two sticky bombs exploded outside the Palace of Justice. The vast majority of sticky bomb attacks reported take place in Iraq, and this latest incident may be further evidence that tactics and bomb making techniques from Iraq are impacting the Syrian insurgency.
A Free Syrian Army (FSA) spokesman claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that they had targeted a military command office with explosives designed to go off at a meeting of army officers and members of the Shabiha.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) militants kidnapped a Kurdish opposition MP in the Ovacik district of Tunceli province.
The deputy head of the Kurdish republican People's Party (CHP) was returning from a visit in Ovacik district to Tunceli when the attack occurred. The militants had set up a roadblock on the route between Ovacik and Tunceli. The politician's aide and a journalist travelling in the car were released unharmed.
The politician was released unharmed 48 hours being captured.
It was the first time that the PKK, who confirmed responsibility for the attack, have kidnapped a member of parliament. The choice of target was also unusual, as he was a pro-Kurdish politician. The PKK later said the kidnapping was to make a political point and send a message to the Turkish government.

The attack occurred as the troops travelled from Hadramaut to the neighbouring Ma'rib governorate. The gunmen then fled the area.
AQAP militants are numerous across the southern governorates of Yemen, and have wrestled with the government for control of several cities and regions. They made no comment on the attack.

summary:
Suspected Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants detonated a car bomb in the Piendamo municipality, Cauca department. Only material damage was caused by the attack.
The car bomb, containing 250kg of explosives, detonated at a bridge over the River Piendamo in the early hours of the morning, causing a traffic problem along the Pan-American Highway.
The attack was the third car bomb within 12 hours in the Cauca department, and the second attack in three months on a river bridge on the Pan-American Highway.
FARC made no comment on the attack.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack. The general had been one of the first officers to defect from the regime of Colonel Gaddafi. There has been an escalation of attacks in Benghazi in recent weeks.

summary:
Suspected Boko Haram gunmen stormed a church near the city of Okene in Kogi state and fired on worshippers. The gunmen killed 17 people.
The attack occurred at the Deeper Life Church, located behind the Federal College of Education in Okene.Survivors of the attack confirmed that gunmen switched off the power before opening fire on the church members. The Pastor and about 15 others died on the spot while one of the members later died in hospital.
No group claimed responsibility but the target and method of attack suggests that Boko Haram was responsible. If verified, this will be one of Boko Haram's most southerly attacks to date.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen attacked the residential building of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) with bombs and rocket-propelled grenades at approxiamtley 0645hrs. Seven aid workers in the building during the attack were not injured; however, the building was damaged extensively.
The incident prompted the ICRC to suspend activities in Misrata and Benghazi. The frequent number of attacks over the past six weeks highlights the high terrorist threat against international aid targets. Nearly a week earlier, seven Iranians working for the International Red Crescent were kidnapped in Benghazi.
The Omar Abdul Rahman Brigades (OARB) group recently issued a comminqu calling on the ICRC to close its offices in Libya. The group also claimed responsibility for recent attacks against the ICRC in Benghazi.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack; however, given past attacks and direct threats, OARB seems most likely responsible.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Militant Islamistsmounted a complex attack on an Egyptian checkpoint close to Gaza on the Egypt-Israel border.According to international media reports, a group of masked gunmen killed 16 Egyptian soldiers, stole an armoured vehicle and then attempted to enter Israel by ramming it through the Kerem Shalom border crossing, before an Israeli airstrike destroyed it. Another vehicle belonging to the attackers exploded on the Egyptian side.
The attacked occurred immediately after Iftar prayers. The militants were reported to have been dressed as masked Bedouin, using guns and RPGs to attack the border post. Eight militants were reported killed in the attack.No group claimed responsibility.
The Rafah border crossing was closed in the wake of the attack.
The incident was the deadliest single attack in Sinai for six years and the most lethal in Egypt since a suicide bombing in Alexandria on 1 July 2011.The scale, boldness and relative sophistication of the attack suggests that the capability of terrorist groups operating in the Sinai is growing. It also underscores the continuing security vacuum in the region that has provided space for them to develop with relative impunity since the fall of the Mubarak regime.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

The US authorities called the attack an act of 'domestic terrorism'. It came just two weeks after a gunman opened fire at a cinema in Colorado, killing 12 people.

summary:
A suicide bomber targeted the a leading cleric at the central mosque in Potiskum, Yobe state. At least six people were injured in the explosion, and several more hurt by shrapnel fragments.

Three weeks prior, another leading cleric in Maiduguri was targeted by Boko Haram. No group claimed responsibility for the latest attack, but Boko Haram are the most likely responsible. They recently claimed responsibility for several attacks across various states and warned that more would come.

summary:
Al-Shabaab militants attempted a suicide bombing at the venue where the new constitution was being endorsed. Security forces prevented the men from entering, and Reuters reported six guards were killed in the attack. Both devices detonated, though the explosions themselves caused no casualties.
The two bombers were thought to have been disguised as delegates of the Constitutional Assembly, and carried the appropriate identification. One militants explosive vest was triggered when he was shot by security personnel. The second bomber detonated his own device.
Al-Shabaab claimed the attack a success, for having reached so close to the venue, and also that several security personnel had been killed in the attempt.
source_urls: BBC Mon - Jowhar; Mareeg; Reuters; Somalia Report; ABC News.go.com

summary:
A man driving a car full of gas cylinders attempted to blow up a police headquarters but was detained by security forces before the attack took place.
The incident occurred outside the entrance of the police headquarters in Khenchela city.
No group claimed the attack but based on the target and location, it is likely that a Sahara based AQIM faction, rather than the group based in the Kabylieregion was responsible.The attack attempt is a considerable distance (300km southeast) from Kabylie, where AQIM's northern command seems to be largely contained in a stalemate situation with the security forces.
The last major suicide attack in the north occurred ten months earlier on 28 August 2011, when AQIM claimed a double suicide car bombing against a military academy in the northern coastal city of Cherchell. The attack killed 18 people and wounded at least 20 others.

summary:
In an afternoon attack, militants exploded two car bombs in Karrada district, central Baghdad. Medical sources cited by the local Arabic press said at least 15 people were killed and 50 others wounded. This attack comes amid high levels of terrorist violence in the country.
According to reports, the first bomb was in Al-Andalus Square and killed six people. The same source said the second bomb exploded five minutes later outside a passport office and killed eight people but did not state in which area of the city.
No group claimed the attack, but based on the location and coordinated nature of the blasts the ISI or an affiliate was most likely responsible. The group claimed coordinated attacks on 23 July, which it described as the first wave of the Razing the Walls' operations' to mark the start of Ramadan.

summary:
Suspected Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) militants detonated an explosion on the Kirkuk-Ceyhan pipeline, close to Midyat, Mardin province, halting the flow of oil between Iraq and Turkey. No casualties were incurred.
The blast started a fire between the villages of Sogutlu and Senkoy, and as a precaution a secondary pipeline was closed. The Kirkuk-Ceyhan line is the largest in the country, carrying a quarter of Iraq's oil, and has been repeatedly sabotaged in the past though usually on the Iraq side. It was unclear when the flow of oil would resume.
There was no claim of responsibility for the attack.

summary: A concealed car bomb wounded the Mufti of Tatarstan in Kazan city.  Ildus Faizov was driving his vehicle when the explosive devices, concealed beneath the passenger side of the car, detonated at the intersection between Musina and Chetayeva streets. He suffered only minor injuries, though the car was burnt out and windows of buildings in the vicinity were shattered.  The attack occurred at the same time that the Mufti's former deputy was shot dead outside of his home.  In a video posted to YouTube, the Emir of the Mujahideen of Tatarstan claimed responsibility for the attack, calling the Mufti an 'enemy of God' and warned that further attacks would be carried out.

summary: An explosion killed eight people on a bus carrying Israeli tourists outside Burgas airport in Bulgaria shortly after 1700hrs.The incident occurred in the city of Burgas, located on the Black Sea. The blast injured at least 32 more people.  The bus was in the parking zone when the blast occurred. The Israeli travelers arrived on the same flight from Israel and boarded seven buses outside the terminal. The blast then occurred, damaging three of the buses.  The incident prompted the closure of the airport, with all incoming flights being diverted elsewhere.  Shortly after the attack, top Israeli officials, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defence Minister Ehud Barakaccused Iran of being behind the attack.Iran has made no public comments to the Israeli accusations.  The incident came on the 18th anniversary of the attack on a Jewish community center in the Argentine capital, Buenos Aires, in which 85 people were killed.  In January, Israel reportedly asked Bulgaria to tighten security for Israeli tourists travelling by bus. Days later,Israelitelevision reported thatBulgarian authoritiesfoiled a bomb attackagainst a bus scheduled totransport Israeli touristsfrom Turkeys border toa Bulgarian ski resort.Bulgarias interior ministrydenied the report, stating thatit had not receivedintelligence from Israelabout a possible terroristattack in the country.  Two days later, Qaedat al-Jihad, an Al-Qaeda linked group, claimed responsibility for the attack in a document sent to the Lebanese newspaper Elnashra. They also threatened further attacks throughout the Ramadan period.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A remotely detonated bomb blast outside a hotel in Mogadishu killed a member of the Somali government, and wounded three bodyguards and two civilians in the vicinity.
MP Mohamud Ibrahim Garweyne had previously been the trade and industries minister. He had been at the Bin Ali hotel in Hamarweyne district when he was targeted. The explosive device had been concealed within his car
Al-Shabaab usually carry out such attacks, and guerrilla-style, suicide attacks have increased in Mogadishu since the group withdrew from the city the previous year. They claimed responsibility for the assassination.

summary:
At least six Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants attacked the Old City Police Station, Bannu, killing one policeman and wounding up to ten more.
The militants entered the police station disguised in burqas, taking several officers hostage, though it was unclear how many policemen had been inside the building at the time of the attack. The siege lasted five hours, before police re-took the building.
One of the militants was killed in the return of fire, two more arrested and another two detonated their suicide vests, killing themselves.
The TTP claimed responsibility for the attack.

The blast targeted the section of line at kilometer 86 that feeds into the Cerrejon coal mine, the largest coal mining operation in the country. It occurred as a train was passing, but failed to derail the train.
Police believed Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants to be responsible, but no group claimed responsibility. The railway line to the mine has been repeatedly attack since the mine started operations.

summary:

The wedding ceremony was being held at the Qasr-e Almas wedding hall, for the daughter of an ethnic Uzbek MP AhmadKhan Samangani. Samangani, along with other senior government and military officials, was killed in the explosion. The bomber was reported to have embraced the MP, and detonated his explosives.
A Taliban spokesman denied involvement in the attack. Samangan is a relatively secure part of country, compared to the south, and such attacks are unusual.

The tribal eldar had been head of the Kamarkhel tribal militia (lashkar), a neutral group formed to defend their area given its location in the center of the Tirah Valley and therefore caught up between Lashkar-e-Islam (LI) and Ansarul Islam (AI) militancy.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary: Four coordinated explosions targeted cash machines in Bannang Sata, Yala province, wounding three people. Shortly after, three grenades were fired at the police station, but missed and struck the nearby police welfare housing. A fifth bomb then detonated inside a dustbin.  No group claimed responsibility, but press reports suggested an insurgent group led by Mukta Alimamae, the leading group of the region, was responsible.

It was the fifth abduction of the year by the Bedouin. Since the overthrow of former President Mubarak, the security situation in the country has deteriorated, especially in the Sinai peninsula, a key tourist location in the country.

summary:
An improvised explosive device attached to a car detonated in Mehtar Lam, killing two people and wounding at least ten more. The blast targeted the director of women's affairs for Laghman province.
The director and her husband were killed when the bomb, magnetically attached to her car, detonated as she drove through the city. Those injured were passers by in the area at the time of the explosion.
Hanifa Safi was the second provincial head of women's affairs to have been killed, since the job was created in 2002.
The attack came days after a video clip gained worldwide prominence. The video portrayed the execution of a woman accused of adultery by the Taliban. Violence against women is though to be on the rise in the country.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
A bomb blast by the Kucklak bazaar killed at least six people and wounded 11 more. Several shops and cars were damaged by the strength of the blast.
The remotely-detonated device, comprising 7 kg of explosives, had been concealed on a bicycle. The blast occurred as a rally for the secular, Pashtun, Awami National Party (ANP) was being conducted. In the wake of the explosion protracted gunfire was reported. The ANP leader was reported to have been amongst the wounded.
The explosion also occurredahead of a visit to the city by Prime Minister Ashraf. On 4 July, gunmen opened fire on officials in the same area.
No group claimed responsibility for the explosion.

summary:
A suicide bomb blast killed four people and wounded six more in Maiduguri, Borno state. The blast targeted the Shehu of Borno, the religious leader of the state at the Central Mosque of the city.
A teenage boy was reported to have carried out the attack on the mosque, which also targeted the deputy governor of the state. Neither leader was wounded in the attack. Security personnel prevented the bomber for reaching the men, causing the explosion to instead killed civilians in the immediate vicinity.
No group claimed responsibility for the blast. Although Boko Haram have repeatedly targeted the city in the past, they have not previously struck at a mosque, instead waging their campaign against Christian targets. However, the previous year, the group claimed responsibility for killing the Shehu's brother, and AFP reported that the group had targeted the Shehu in the past.
source_urls: Xinhua. ESISC; All Africa; AFP; This Day

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a police academy located in the centre of Sana'a, killing at least 20 people and injuring dozens.
Yemeni officials confirmed the attacks, stating that the bomber had blown himself up among a crowd of cadets as they left the academy after classes finished for the day.The timing of the attack suggests that the bomber or accomplices carried out reconnaissance on the building prior to the attack and timed the bombing to maximise casualty numbers. It is likely that the police academy was targeted in a bid to discourage others from joining Yemen's security forces.
The police academy is located on Shawkani Street, a main axis road leading from the 70 meters road  where the 21 May attack took place  north towards the Tahrir Square in the city centre. It was the second suicide attack against the capital city within two months.
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the attack.
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Education Sector

summary:

The group were undertaking a search and rescue mission for a missing pilot believed to have crashed into the river. The group had camped by the side of the river when gunmen opened fire at them from a bridge crossing the river.
Such militant activity is usually more common in the northwestern areas of the country, and is much rarer in Punjab. Hours prior to the attack, a "long march" had passed through the area, protesting the re-opening of the NATO supply routes through the country.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
A roadside bomb blast killed one police officer and wounded three more in Peshawar.
The remotely detonated device targeted a passing police vehicle that was on a routine patrol of the city. The explosion occurred on the Ring Road, in the area under the jurisdiction of Pishtakhara police station.
The device was considered small by police, containing only 500 kg of explosives, concealed in a rice cooker.
Several months prior, a vehicle was targeted in a bomb blast in the same area, as well as another police patrol a year ago.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Suspected members of the New People's Army (NPA) raided a gold mining company in the southern Philippines town of Rosario, taking three workers hostage.
Approximately 30 NPA militants stormed into the VTO Mining company office in Agusan del Sur province. Theowner's son and two employees were seized, along with five shotguns and nine .45 caliber pistols belonging to the security guards.
A day later, militants demandedP25 million in exchange for the hostages. Three days after seizing the men, they were released. Local officials and military personnel declined to say whether the ransom had been paid to facilitate the release.
On 6 July, the NPA released the hostages.

No group claimed responsibility.

summary:

The contractors had been working for the state-run petroleum company Ecopetrol when the guerrillas attacked with grenades and small arms fire. Several vehicles were also set alight in the attack.
The incident occurred in the Putumayo province, near the border with Ecuador. The 32nd Front of FARC were thought to be responsible for launching the attack on the oil well. The attack came a day after Ecuador urged Colombian authorities to increase security along the border, to prevent militants from launching an attack in Colombia then escaping across the border into Ecuador.
No group claimed responsibility.

The university is located approximately 2 km from the former base of Taliban leader Mullah Omar. The area was currently used as a base for US special forces, and the majority of casualties were reported to be local Afghans working for the US base.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Suspected Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants attacked a police station in southwestern Colombia, close to the town of Argelia. One civilian was killed in the attack, and nine policemen wounded.
The clash occurred in El Mango, a village in the central part of the Cauca department. The guerrillas were believed to be from the 60th Front of FARC, and used grenades, gunfire and homemade tatuco bombs (constructed from gas cylinders) to target the police station and a police patrol. Several civilian homes were also destroyed or damaged, causing people to flee to near-by villages.
The attack lasted over 12 hours.
No group claimed responsibility.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen launched simultaneous attacks against Christian churches in Garissa, killing 17 people including two policemen, and wounding at least 45 others.
Guns and grenades were used in the attacks, which targeted a military town used as a base from which military operations against Al Shabaab were launched. A Catholic Church and an African Inland Church, located 3 km apart, were targeted, however, Garissa itself was a predominantly Muslim town. The militants threw grenades and fired at the church congregations during the service, forcing the people to flee out of the building where more attackers opened fire.
The attacks resembled the tactics carried out by Boko Haram in Nigeria. No group claimed responsibility.

summary:
Six Uighurs attempted to hijack a plane after it departed from Hotan airport, Xinjiang province. Passengers and crew foiled the attempt, though ten people were injured.
The Tianjin Airlines plane had departed from Hotan airport and was 10 minutes into the flight when the six people attempted to violently seize control. The plane had been destined for the provincial capital, Urumqi. Passengers and crew subdued the hijackers, who were arrested as the plane returned to Hotan.
Two security guards sustained serious injuries, a flight attendant and seven passengers sustained minor wounds.
The motive behind the attempt was not reported, and no group claimed responsibility.
source_urls: Reuters; The Telegraph; The Guardian; AFP

summary:
Suspected Al Shabaab militants attacked a police post close to Mandera, on the border between Somalia and Kenya. No casualties were reported in the attack.
Gunmen attacked the Arabia Administration Police Post, sparking a gunfight with the police. The regional deputy police commander reported that the intended target was believed to be the main shop in the area, and that militants had fled back across the border with stolen goods.
The attack came hours after gunmen kidnapped four foreign aid workers form the Dadaab refugee camp in Kenya. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though Al Shabaab have made repeated threats of reprisal on Kenyan soil, after Kenyan troops were deployed to Somalia to combat the militant group.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen kidnapped four foreign aid workers from the Dadaab refugee camp. A local driver was killed and two others wounded in the attack.
Gunmen ambushed a convoy of the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), killing one Kenyan driver in the process before driving away with four aid workers.The hostages were reported to be from Canada, Norway, and the Philippines. The Secretary General of the NRC had also been travelling in the convoy, but was unharmed. The two wounded locals were a second driver and a contractor to the NRC.
The stolen vehicle was later found abandoned.
Police suspected the kidnappers of being sympathisers of Al Shabaab.The attack was the first kidnapping of foreigners since Kenya sent troops into Somalia in October 2011 to help combat the threat of Al Shabaab. Al Shabaab in Somalia claimed to have no knowledge of the attack.
Three days after the abduction, a joint operation by Kenyan and Somali troops rescued the hostages unharmed. One militant was killed in the operation.
source_urls: Xinhua; Reuters; AP; AFP; BBC News

summary:
A suicide car bomber detonated his explosives outside the National Gendarmerie headquarters in Ouargla. One gendarme officer was killed in the blast, and three more wounded.
The bomber reportedly attempted to enter the building, which is located in a residential neighbourhood. He detonated his explosives following a clash with officers as he tried to enter the premises. The blast caused structural damage to the entrance-way and surrounding buildings.
The suspected AQIM splinter group, Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa (MOJWA) claimed the attack. Ouargla was a relatively safe province, but spillover from the insecurity in Libya and Mali has caused the security to deteriorate in the area.

summary:
Taliban militants launched multiple attacks against Afghan National Army checkpoints in the Kamdesh district of Nuristan province. At least three civilians were killed and several more wounded, though specific casualty numbers were unavailable.
60 to 80 militants launched the attacks against the checkpoints, initiating clashes that lasted several hours. Government offices and the homes of the local governor and police commander were reported to have been set alight during the attack.
The provincial governor reported that at least 20 militants were killed during the clash, that involved guns and RPGs. Nuristan province borders Pakistan and an anonymous official reported that Pakistani fighters had cooperated with Afghan Taliban in the attack.
The Taliban reported they had captured several of the checkpoints during the clash, but this was unverified by other sources.

summary:
Ansar Dine militants destroyed six sacred sites in Timbuktu, and warned that others will be targeted.
The shrines in the region have been UNESCO World Heritage sites since 1988, but Ansar Dine claim the monuments are un-Islamic, and have targeted them as part of their push to impose Sharia law across the country.
Starting Friday, the militants set tombs alight, and threatened people who approached the tombs to pray. They also used pickaxes and chisels to smash several locations.Local residents reported that the militants threatened to destroy all the sites in the area.

summary:
Unidentified assailants attacked Microsoft's headquarters in Athens by driving a van through the front doors and setting it on fire.
Three people inside the stolen van forced the two security guards in the building to leave at gun-point before they reversed the van into the front entrance, smashing the door. The assailants then triggered an incendiary device inside the van which contained three inflammable gas canisters and five cans of gasoline.
The fire destroyed the van, damaged the building's front entrance and lobby floor. The fire brigade estimated the damage to be worth about 60,000 euros (48,000). There were no reported injuries.
Growing public anger at the impact of the austerity measures has resulted in an increase in the number of arson attacks over the past three years, which are often blamed on left-wing extremist. However, no group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Five Taliban militants attacked a hotel at Lake Qargha, outside Kabul, initiating a 12 hour siege that left at least 15 people dead.
Militants attacked the Spozhmai Hotel, a popular destination for day trips from Kabul. The Taliban claimed that the hotel was a site for wealthy Afghans and foreigners to host "wild parties". The hotel had been full, as civilians started the weekend by visiting the remote part of the lake.
The Taliban had been able to convey RPGs, machine guns and rifles to the site, raising questions about the security provision of the area. US military commander in Afghanistan, General Allen, stated the attack bore the hallmarks of the Haqqani militant faction.
The Taliban claimed responsibility, citing the hotel as a site of drinking and prostitution.

summary:
An Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) suicide bomber assassinated the military commander of the southern military region in Aden. Four other soldiers and a passer-by were wounded by the explosion.
Major-General Salim Ali Qatan was travelling in a convoy on his way to work, when the bomber, wearing an explosive belt, threw himself at his vehicle. The Defence Ministry identified the bomber as a Somali national.
AQAP claimed the attack was in revenge for the increased pressure on the US-led campaign against militants in the Abyan governorate, which had recently resulted in forcing militants from three towns that had previously been under their control. summary:
Two suicide car bomb blasts targeted worshippers at church services in Zaria, Kaduna state, on Sunday morning. Initial casualty numbers stated at least 15 people had been killed.
The coordinated attacks occurred at the Christ the King Catholic Cathedral in Sabon Gari, and ECWA Good News church in Wassa. Both areas had been targeted in the past by Boko Haram. The bombers drove their explosive-laden vehicles into the front gates of the churches. An ongoing gun fight between police and the militants was reported in one of the churches after the explosion.
Boko Haram claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement emailed to the media. They have carried out strings of attacks against Christian Sunday church services since the start of 2012, in a bid to recreate an Islamic state with strict adherence to Sharia law in the country.
source_urls: Reuters; Xinhua; Vanguard Nigeria; Al Jazeera; Naij; My Joy Online
targets: Religious Institutions; Civilians/General Public; Public Spaces
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Boko Haram, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomb blast targeted a church in Kaduna city, barely an hour after a twin attack on churches in nearby Zaria town. Initial casualty numbers suggested two people had been killed and an uncertain number wounded.
The blast occurred at the Shalom Church in the Tirkaniya area of the city. Security personnel stopped the bomber at the entrance to the church, where the explosives then detonated.
Christian youths were reported to have gone on a rampage after the three blasts, dragging Muslims from cars and killing them in retaliation for the bombings.
Boko Haram claimed responsibility for the attacks in a statement emailed to the media. The group had carried out a consistent wave of attacks against Sunday Christian church services since the start of 2012. They have been seeking to drive Christians out and establish an Islamic state under Sharia law in the country.
source_urls: Xinhua; Reuters;Vanguard Nigeria;  News.Naij; My Joy Online
targets: Religious Institutions; Public Spaces; Civilians/General Public

summary:
A car bomb targeted a Shia pilgrim procession in the Al-Shu'ala neighbourhood of northwest Baghdad, killing 14 people and wounding 32 more.
The pilgrims had been participating in commemoration ceremonies of the death of Imam Musa Kadhim. The blast originated from a taxi which had been abandoned on the road the pilgrims used as they returned home from the ceremony. The force of the detonation flung cars up to 100 metres away. Four cars and two minibuses were burnt by the blast.
The blast came three days after a series of attacks by the Al Qaeda front, the Islamic State of Iraq, that killed 72 people across the country. Two days before that the group had issued a statement, claimed responsibility for an attack on 4 June, and stating that more devastating attacks were to come.
No responsibility for the latest attack was claimed.
source_urls: Reutesr; Xinhua; Al Jazeera; BBC News; AFP
targets: Civilians/General Public; Public Spaces; Religious Institutions

summary:
A suicide car bomb detonated by a Shia pilgrimage in the Kadhimiyah area of Baghdad, killing at least 18 people and wounding 36 more.
The blast occurred just two hours after another car bomb targeted pilgrims in the Al-Shu'ala neighbourhood, close by. The second blast occurred close to Sana'a Square, and targeted pilgrims who had been commemorating the anniversary of the death of the Imam Musa Kadhim. The day's ceremony had been the culmination of the week-long religious ceremony. Witnesses reported the car bomb struck a minibus, causing the explosion.
The religious ceremony had been taking place all week. Despite the increase in security, the Islamic State of Iraq (IS), a front of Al Qaeda in the country, carried out a wave of attacks nation-wide three days earlier. ISI also claimed responsibility for an attack on 4 June against the Shia endowment office in Baghdad.
source_urls: Xinhua; Reuters; AFP; Al Jazeera; BBC News;

No group claimed responsibility for the attack. However, the tactics and targets suggest the involvement of the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), which have been carrying out violent attacks to destabilise the country.
The incident occurred as a Shia pilgrimage was taking place, and was part of a wave of attacks targeting security forces and pilgrims.

summary:
Eight explosive devices were defused by army sappers along a stretch of road in Aleppo.
The devices ranged from 15 to 40kg of explosive and were laid along the Khan al-Asal road, which led to the Police Academy. They had been primed for remote detonation when the military engineers defused them.
No group claimed responsibility. Syria has been facing an armed uprising since March 2011, and the civilian protests have been exploited by terrorist groups as the internal instability has escalated.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide car bomb wounded 14 people in Sayyida Zaynab, a Shia suburb south of Damascus. The device exploded near a police station and one of Syria's most important Shia pilgrimage sites. It is unclear what the primary target was.
According to Associated Press, which cited witnesses at the scene, the bomb exploded in a car park about 50m from the shrine of Sayyida Zaynab, which is 8km south of central Damascus. Images published on the state-controlled SANA news network showed damaged cars and buses.
As well as being widely known as a Shia residential district, Sayyida Zaynab attracts Shia pilgrims from around the world - but most prominently Iranians. The attack damaged tourist buses as well as civilian cars.
Although the incident took place close to the shrine, two government security buildings were located close to the attack site. Similarly, AP reported that the bomb detonated close to a police station, which may have been the intended target.
targets: Public Spaces; Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jabhat al-Nusra (JaN/Al-Nusra Front), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

summary:
A Jordanian journalist and two Filipino colleagues were missing, suspected kidnapped by Aby Sayyaf militants, from Sulu province.
The men had departed for a trip into the jungle area, and failed to appear at work the next day. The Sulu governor stated that the men were only "missing" and not believed to have been abducted by militants, but an unnamed government official contradicted this, claiming the men were in the hands of the militants.
The Philippine Star media group later reported that a P50 million ransom had been demanded.
There was no claim of responsibility, but the area is frequented by Abu Sayaaf militants who have repeatedly kidnapped foreigners in the past.

summary:
A suicide car bomb detonated in front of NATO Forward Operating Base Salerno, outside of Khost City. There were conflicting reports on casualty number but at least seven Afghan construction workers were thought to have been killed in the explosion, and 13 others wounded.
Later reports stated two American soldiers had also been killed, and over 100 wounded, though mostly suffering minor injuries.
The explosive-laden lorry was reported to have driven into the first security post outside of the base.
A Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility for the attack, and also that following the the explosion more Taliban militants had attacked the base.

summary:
A twin grenade attack wounded at least eight people in the Dadaab area of Kenya.
The attacks occurred 10 minutes apart, with the first targeting a school construction site at the Ifo camp. A grenade was thrown at the site where the construction workers were resting, wounding five of them. All of the wounded were non-Somali nationals.
In the second attack a grenade was thrown at the Dubai Lodge hotel in Wajir, which was popular with government officials. The hotel was located on the road leading to the military camp, and close to the government club that was targeted in 2011. Three people were reported wounded in the second attack.
Al Shabaab are the principle suspects behind similar attacks in the region, which have been escalating since the deployment of Kenyan Defence Forces into Somalia to deal with Al Shabaab. No claim of responsibility was made.

summary:
A suicide car bomb killed two police officers and two suicide bombers in Kayseri, a province in central Turkey. At least 19 people sustained injuries in the explosion, including ten children.
Although the explosion took place outside the police department complex of Pnarba......  district, the interior minister said the sequence of events strongly suggests that the police complex was not the intended target. He added that an investigation was underway to determine what the bombers intended target may have been.
The two assailants caught the attention of police when they drove through a checkpoint on the Kahramanmaras-Kayseri motorway. Police and security forces then pursued the vehicle, which changed direction and headed towards the Pnarba......  police complex. Prior to the explosion, a fire-fight took place between police and the two suicide bombers.
A day after the attack, the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) claimed responsibility, stating the Pinarbasi had been the intended target, in response to Turkey's military attacks.
area: Pinarbasi, Kayseri province, Central Anatolia region
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide car bomber drove his vehicle into the entrance of a school in Hazm, Al-Jawf governorate, destroying the entrance way and killing 18 people and wounding several more.
The bomber targeted the Hazm town, which is held by Shiite Houthi rebels. The bomber targeted the building as a group gathered for a meeting. Several children who were passing the school were caught up in the explosion, though there were no confirmations of the number of wounded.
The attack came a week after Partisans of Sharia, an Al-Qaeda affiliate in the country, announced threats against Houthi areas in Al Jawf, Hajjja and Saada. Earlier in the same day, a suicide bomber was prevented from detonating his device during a Houthi protest march in Saada.
Sunii Al-Qaeda affiliates view the Shiite Houthi, who have been waging their own uprising against the government since 2004, as heretics. The continued internal turmoil in Yemen has allowed numerous factions, including those of Al-Qaeda, to take control and exploit the instability for their own benefit.
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the attack, stating it was part of a plan to target groups that had links to Iran.
perpetrators: Saudi Arabia:Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP):Global Islamist
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: 11 Lebanese Shiite pilgrims were kidnapped in Aleppo as they returned home from a pilgrimage in Iran.  The men had been travelling by bus when their vehicle was stopped by gunmen. summary:
A suicide bomb attack during a practice drill for a parade killed at least 90 soldiers in the centre of Sanaa.
Soldiers had assembled in al-Sabeen Square for a rehersal in advance of a military parade the following day that was to celebrate National Unity Day. The bomber had been wearing military uniform, and participating in the drill.
There have been continual clashes between the military and Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) in the southern governorates, but this was the group's first mass-casualty attack in Sanaa since its inception in January 2009.
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and its affiliate Ansar al-Sharia (Partisans of Islamic Law) both claimed responsibilty.
The suicide bomber was identified as Ameen Addin Ali al Wirafi from Ibb governorate. Wirafi was arrested in 2007 for his ties to al Qaeda and for alleged attempts to carry out suicide attacks against government installations in Ma'rib and Hadramawt governorates.

summary:

Venezuela responded by increasing security along the border, and repeating the declaration that they would not allow militants to hide or train in their country.

There has been as escalation, both of bombings, and of the targeting of government intelligence sites, amidst the continuation of the uprising that broke out in March 2011. summary:
Unidentified gunmen assassinated senior Afghan peace negotiator Arsala Rahmani as he made his way to work.
Gunmen fired a single, silenced bullet at the car in which Mr Rahmani, a member of the High Peace Council and former Taliban minster, was travelling in the west of Kabul. The gunmen had fired from a passing car, and fled in the vehicle after the attack.
Mr Rahmani had received threats against his life in the past, and a key figure for President Karzai's government for his insights to the Taliban, and role as mediator and go-between during talks.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Taliban spokesmanZabiullah Mujahid stated that although the Taliban had threatened the High Peace Council during the announcement of the start of the Taliban's spring offensive, he denied Taliban involvement with the assassination.

summary:
Twin suicide car bombs detonated at the Qazaz intersection of Damascus' southern bypass just before 0800hrs. At least 55 people were killed and up to 400 others were wounded.
The first explosion brought emergency services and bystanders to the area, before a second, larger device targeted first responders. The blasts occurred outside a military intelligence building in the city, and the strength of the explosion ripped the front of the building off. The timing of the blasts targeted workers and children on their morning routes.
The Syrian government claimed up to a tonne of explosives had been used, with over 200 cars damaged in the attack, which brings the total number of bombings in the capital to seven since the start of April.
Both the Free Syrian Army, and the government, blamed each other for the attack. On 12 May, the militant Islamist group the Al-Nusra Front posted a video claiming responsibility for the attack. The group claimed the attacks were retaliatory strikes against the government for strikes that had been carried out on residential neighbourhoods that targeted the Sunni populace.
The veracity of the video was undetermined.
source_urls: AP; BBC; AFP; Xinhua; The Telegraph

summary:
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants attacked El Retorno municipality, causing material damage and killing two policemen. Two civilians were also wounded in the attack.
The guerrillas attacked the police station, a Comcel mobile phone tower, and homes of the mayor and various residents. The damage to the tower caused the outage of the mobile phone network for the whole city. Communications have been limited, as the town has no landline connectivity.
The army claimed that the attack had been carried out by a new faction of FARC, calling itselfVctor Saavedra.

summary:
Taliban militants attacked police checkpoints surrounding the Yahyakhel district administrative building. Three policemen and two civilians were killed and two more officers wounded in the attack.
Six militants wearing suicide vests attacked the checkpoints, attempting to gain access to the administrative building. Four were killed in the return of fire by the police, whilst the remaining two detonated their suicide vests. The clash lasted an hour.
The Taliban claimed responsibilty, though exaggerated the number of victims. Security personnel have been frequent targets of attack, which have occurred near-daily since the start of the Taliban's spring offensive on 03 May this year.

summary:
A lone gunman shot the head of an Italian nuclear engineering company as he left his home on Via Montello in Genoa. The gunman escaped on a stolen moped with an accomplice.
The gunman, who hit the Ansaldo executive in the knee, was a member of the Olga cell, a faction of the Informal Anarchist Federation (FAI), as claimed in a letter posted to the Italian paper Corriere della Sera. They claimed the attack was to punish "one of the many sorcerers of the atomic industry".
The Ansaldo group belongs to the Italian aerospace and defence corporation Finmeccanica, who were targeted by the far-left Red Brigades movement in the 1970s and 1980s. The FAI claimed responsibility for a parcel-bomb in December 2011 that targeted a tax collection office in Rome.

summary: A car bomb blast in the Al-Sukhari area of Aleppo killed at least three people, and wounded 20 more. summary:
A grenade attack at a church killed one person and wounded at least 15 more in the Ngara neighbourhood of Nairobi.
The grenade targeted God's House of Miracles Church, and was reported to have been thrown by a member of the congregation inside the church.
The attack came in the wake of a US embassy warning that attacks were in the final stages of being planned against the city. The previous month a twin grenade attack occurred in Mombassa.
Al-Shabaab have previously threatened Kenya for sending troops across the border into Somalia to fight against Al-Shabaab militants. Kenyan police stated thatSheikh Ismail Ali, an Al-Shabaab leader, claimed responsibility for the attack, and promised to send more suicide bombers across from Somlia to target Kenya.
