summary:
A French journalist and five Colombian security personnel were kidnapped following an attack by Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants in Caqueta department. Three soldiers and a policeman were killed in the attack and another four wounded.
The France 24 journalist had been accompanying a military patrol in the La Montaita area when FARC guerrillas attacked. The patrol had been on an anti-drugs operation at the time.
Although FARC released the last of their 10 military and police hostages at the start of April, they have continued to launch small-scale attacks against security personnel and operations. On 2 May, the Colombian Army announced that FARC had confirmed they were holding the journalist hostage. The army was suspending operations in the area south ofCaquet in order to ease negotiations for the journalist's release.
On 30 May, FARC released the journalist after 33 days of captivity.

summary:
Up to ten explosions were reported across the Dnipropetrovsk within 70 minutes. At least 27 people were wounded.
The first explosion occurred at 1150hours at a tram stop on Serova street, close to the city's opera house. 13 people were wounded when a device detonated inside a dustbin.
30 minutes later, 11 people, nine of whom were children, were wounded in an explosion by a cinema. The third blast occurred by a railway station, wounding three people. A fourth blast, with no reported casualties, occurred in the city centre.
Other explosions were reported by local media as occurring on Pravda Avenue, and also the quayside. A second explosion was also thought to have occurred at the tram stop, as people arrived to respond to the first blast. The improvised explosive devices appeared to have all been concealed inside dustbins, and were planted along one single tram route.
Dnipropetrovsk is the fourth largest city in the Ukraine, based on the Dniper river, with an large aerospace industry. It is also located in the Russian-speaking area of the country The country is due to co-host the Euro 2012 football tournament with Poland in June, though Dnipropetrovsk is not one of the tournament cities.
In November 2011, a bomb blast inside a dustbin wounded one man, though the incident was thought to have been criminally motivated. No warning or claim of responsibility was made relating to the series of attacks.
targets: Public Transportation; Civilians/General Public; Public Spaces
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomb blast killed at least nine people and wounded 29 more, by the Zain al-Abidin mosque in the al-Midan area of Damascus.
A security bus parked beneath a flyover, and intended to prevent anti-government protests at the mosque, was thought to have been the intended target of the blast. The al-Midan neighbourhood has been the site of frequent anti-government protests. The bomber was reported to have been wearing military uniform, and detonated his vest when challenged by security officials. Worshippers had been leaving the mosque following Friday prayers when the blast occurred.
Government media reported that unidentified gunmen opened fire on the crowds in the wake of the explosion.
The explosion came in the wake of several blasts across the country earlier in the day, and coinciding with the deployment of UN observers to the country in order to monitor the attempted ceasefire.
On 29 April, the al-Nusra Front claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that the attack had not been carried by the Zain al-Abidin mosque, but rather at a location where security personnel gathered to conduct Friday prayers. The bomber had waited until the gathering peaked at 150 personnel before detonating his device.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jabhat al-Nusra (JaN/Al-Nusra Front), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide car bomber crashed an explosive-laden vehicle into the offices of a major newspaper in Abuja, killing at four people and injuring many others. Shortly after the attack, a bomb exploded at another ThisDay office in Kaduna.
The blast caused severe material damage to the nearby commerical and residential buildings. One security guard and three passers-by were killed by the explosion.
Boko Haram claimed responsibility for the attack. They had previously warned that the media would be targeted. In the wake of the explosion, spokesman Abul Qaqa said that the organisation would not stand for being misrepresented in the press, nationally or internationally. They claimed that the media were not objective but sided with the government in their reporting of Boko Haram activities.

summary:
A French Red Cross aid worker was kidnapped as he returned from the Hajjah governorate to the port city of Al Hudaydah.
Two Yemeni drivers with the aid worker were released shortly after the Frenchman was seized. The attack occurred as their car stopped on the road 30km outside of Al Hudaydah, in the Al Zaidiai district. It is the second kidnapping of a western national, following the abduction of a Swiss woman by Al-Qaeda militants a month earlier.
No demands have yet been made. Kidnappings by tribesmen are frequent in Yemen, as a means of pressuring for the release of relatives. Most are released unharmed. No group claimed responsibility.
On 13 July, three months after the abduction, the aid worker was released. An ICRC spokesman said only that it was not ICRC policy to pay ransom. The identity of the kidnappers remained unknown.
source_urls: Xinhua; Reuters; Washington Post; Gulf News; ESISC
area: Al Zaidiai district, Al Hudaydah governorate
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) supporters hijacked a ferry boat on the Elbe river at Hamburg. No injuries were incurred in the incident.
Nine supporters waited until the boat was underway, before surrounding the captain and refusing to let the boat return to shore. They waved flags in support of the imprisoned PKK leader. Police arrested the supporters after freeing the ferry passengers.
It was the second such incident within seven days, after a boat was hijacked in Cologne.

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants clashed with members of the Haqqani network in the Malik Shadam Khan area. Ongoing retaliatory attacks started in the early hours of Thursday night and continued for two days. At least eight people were reported dead from the attacks, and local residents were fleeing the area to escape the clashes.
The bodies of two men kidnapped in the clashes were dumped in the Mir Ali area Friday night. Both men were family members of a tribal elder of the area. The TTP also issued a threat to the elder, to leave the area within 20 days or all his family would be killed.

summary:
Armed Islamists seized the Algerian consulate in Gao, taking seven diplomats hostage, including the Algerian Consul. 
The Movement for the Oneness and Jihad in West Africa (MUJAO) officially claimed responsibility for the kidnapping on 8 April through a telephone message to Agence France Presse (AFP).The group's spokesperson, Adnan Abu Walid Sahraoui, demanded a 15 million ransom for the release of the diplomats, as well as the release of prisoners detained in Algeria and Mauritania.
MUJAO was also holding three humanitarian workers which it kidnapped in October in Algeria.
On 10 April, three of the hostages were released following negotiations between the militants and Algerian authorities.
On 01 September, MUJAO claimed to have executed one diplomat, the vice-consul, after the failure of the Algerian government to release several arrested militants by the deadline.

summary:

AQAP confirmed responsibility of the attack.

summary:
Unidentified suicide bomber blew up his explosive-laden vehicle and killed up to five civilians and wounded 28 others in the district of Alawi central Baghdad.
The attack was part of a series of co-ordinated bombings across Iraq which killed at least 50 and injured more than 200. Attacks took place in Baghdad, Kirkuk, Baiji, Samarra, Tuz Khurmato, Daquq and Dhuluiya, Hilla and Latifiya between 0700hrs and 0830hrs. The attacks came on the nine-year anniversary of the United States' invasion of Iraq, and days before Baghdad was due to hold an Arab League summit.
The attacks were carried out despite heightened security in Baghdad in preparation for the Arab League summit. Holding the summit is seen as an important landmark for the Iraqi government. The attacks may have been intended to undermine confidence in the government at this important time.
The Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Attacks took place in Baghdad, Kirkuk, Baiji, Samarra, Tuz Khurmato, Daquq and Dhuluiya, Hilla and Latifiya between 0700hrs and 0830hrs. The attacks came on the nine-year anniversary of the United States' invasion of Iraq, and days before Baghdad was due to hold an Arab League summit.
The attacks were carried out despite heightened security in Baghdad in preparation for the Arab League summit. Holding the summit is seen as an important landmark for the Iraqi government. The attacks may have been intended to undermine confidence in the government at this important time.
The Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility.

summary:
A gunman opened fire at parents and children arriving at the Ozar Hatorah Jewish School in Toulouse. A teacher and three children were killed, before the shooter escaped on a scooter.
The shooter was later identified as Mohammed Merah, a 23 year old Frenchman of Algerian descent. He claimed to have been inspired by Al-Qaeda (AQ), and that he had trained in AQ camps in Afghanistan and Pakistan. Along with his older brother, he was believed to have had links with the AQ-affiliated group Jund al-Khilafah. Four days after the attack the group alleged that Merah was a member and that they were thus responsible for the attack. The claim remained unverified.
Merah had filmed his attack and was thought to have posted clips online. He had been known to intelligence officials, and had been on the U.S. no-fly list.
A 30-hour standoff followed the attack after security officers tracked Merah down. He was killed by a gunshot as he jumped from a window in his apartment, firing at police officers.
Merah also claimed responsibility for thekillings of four soldiers in two separate incidents hte previous Thursday and Sunday in the same region. Merah had alleged the attack was revenge for both the killings of Palestinian children, and also French military actions.Jund al-Khilafah claimed responsibility for the attack. The group claimed to have trained Merah when he travelled to Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Jund al-Khilafah group has previously only carried out attacks in Pakistan and Afghanistan.
source_urls: liberation; le monde; bbc; The Guardian; Reuters

summary:
Twin car bombs targeted security headquarters in Damascus, killing 27 people and wounding over 100.
The initial reports said two parked vehicles filled with explosives caused the explosions. The first blast targeted the Criminal Security Department at the al-Jamarek roundabout, whilst the second was directed at the Air Intelligence Directorate at al-Tahrir square. As rescue workers attended to the latter explosion, a spate of gunfire occurred. The attack on the Air Directorate occurred near the mostly Christian al-Qassaa neighbourhood.
The attack came two days after the first anniversary of the uprising against President Assad. On 20 March, the al-Nusra Front claimed responsibility for the attacks via jihadist forums, claiming they were revenge strikes against the government for it's action against the people. It was the first time the group issued a written communique, having previously released video statements.
source_urls: Xinhua; Al Arabiya; Al Jazeera; Dawn;

attributions: perpetrator_name: Jabhat al-Nusra (JaN/Al-Nusra Front), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants attacked soldiers on patrol, killing 11 in Arauquita. Two others were also wounded.
FARC were believed to have used home-made missiles to target the troops. During the attack, the guerrillas also looted rifles and radios from the patrol.
The area of attack was being explored by oil companies, and soldiers frequently patrol in order to protect both the oil installations and petrol tanker road transport as rebels frequently launch attacks.
FARC made no statement about the attack, which was one of the most severe since October 2011 when 20 soldiers were killed during two attacks.

summary:
Two Italian tourists were kidnapped by alleged Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) rebels in the central Kandhamal district of Orissa.
The two tourists were travelling in the Daringbadi area.The Maoists issued a list of demands to the press, including the release of detained militants and an end to anti-militant operations, in return for the men's return.
Kandhamal district has seen an ongoing insurgency by the CPI-M for several decades. Maoist rebels have targeted government officials and police officers in the past. This is the first time foreign tourists have been taken hostage.
11 days after the abduction, one Italian was released on 25 March, after the crew of a television news channel hiked out to the place where the men had been held for him to be handed over. The other Italian was released on 12 April.

summary:
A gunman on a scooter shot and killed a soldier in Toulouse.
The soldier was originally from Morocco and had been deployed to the Ivory Coast, Chad and Gabon. The .45 caliber gun used to kill the soldier was the same used to kill three soldiers and wound another one in Montauban the following Thursday.
The shooter was later identified as Mohammed Merah. Following an attack on a Jewish school, he was held in a 30-hour standoff with police before being killed.Jund al-Khilafah claimed responsibility for the attack. The group claimed to have trained Merah when he travelled to Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Jund al-Khilafah group has previously only carried out attacks in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

summary:
A suicide bomb blast at a funeral killed 13 people and wounded at least 32 others inBadabher, east of Peshawar.
Police reported that the target of the attack was the Deputy Speaker of the province, who had been attending the funeral. He had departed 10 minutes before the explosion occurred and was unharmed. People had begun to leave the funeral when the bomb exploded.
Two hand grenades and ammunition was reported to have been found nearby. 8kgs of explosive were thought to have been used in the blast.
It was the second explosion in the same area within two months. The Darra Adam Khel faction of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the attack, confirming the political as the target of the attack.

summary:
A suspected suicide car bomb targeted a Catholic Church in Jos. Initial reports confirmed at least ten people were killed.
The explosion occurred at St. Finber Catholic Churc, in the Rayfield area of the city. The casualty figure was believed to be high, after the blast occurred midway through the main Sunday mass. The bomber was thought to have detonated his device after being prevented from entering the church facility.
It was the first attack in that area of the city, which was normally under heavy guard by both the army and troops from the Joint Task Force. Rayfield is a Government Reservation Area, housing many current and ex-serving public officers. There were reports that soldiers opened fire indiscriminately in the wake of the explosion.
Boko Haram have claimed responsibility for a wave of bomb blasts targeting churches within the country, including several in Jos since the start of the year. The previous church attack occurred two weeks' prior.
No responsibility for the latest attack was claimed.
source_urls: Reuters; Nationonlineng.net; Daily Times Nigeria; BBC News; AP

summary:
Al-Shabaab militants attacked an Ethiopian troop base in southern Somalia. At least 23 people were killed in the attack on Yurkudvillage in the southern Gedo region.
TheAl-Shabaab spokesman Sheikh Abu Musab claimed that they had carried out the attack, with at least 70 soldiers being killed. He also admitted five militants had died in the clash. These claims were not substantiated by local witnesses, who suggested up to 17 militants were killed.
Reports claimed very heavy fighting lasted several hours near to the town of Baidoa. Ethiopian troops entered Somalia at the start of 2012 as part of a military offensive to contain the Al-Shabaab threat. The attack came in the wake of the announcement that Ethiopian troops would pull out at the end of April, being replaced with soldiers of other African nations.

summary:
Dozens of unidentified gunmen, wearing military-style uniforms, attacked checkpoints and homes in Haditha, 220km northwest of Baghdad. The attack killed at least 27 membersof the security forcesand injured 3 others. The 27 victims included two senior officers who were kidnapped from their homes and then killed. During the carefully coordinated assault, the attackers drove cars that had been painted to look like Iraqi interior ministry vehicles. Gunfights ensued at the checkpoints where the attacks happened.
According to one official, the gunmen raised the 'Al-Qaeda flag' at one of the checkpoints.Al-Qaeda in Iraq (otherwise known as the Islamic State of Iraq) later claimed responsibility on 15 March, stating in posts on jihadist forums that the raid had been called "Invasion of Commander Jarrahal-Shami".
source_urls: BBC; Reuters; Xinhua; Site Intel Group

summary:
Al-Qaeda militants attacked an army post in Kud, south of Zinjibar. Up to 78 Yemeni soldiers were reported killed in the attack. There were unverified reports that over 70 soldiers had also been captured by the militants and 25 released the day after.
Militants attacked the army forward base in Kud, before clashes spread to other posts on the ouskirts of Zinjibar city. Two vehicle borne improved explosive devices (VBIEDs) detonated at two of the army posts, sparking gunbattles between soldiers and militants. One blast at the western entrance to Zanjibar killed seven people. The second VBIED detonated by an artillery position at the southern entrance of the city. The number of casualties was not known.
25 militants were also killed in the attack. There were reports that as the militants retreated, they seized heavy weapons.
The area has been under continuous fighting, and from May 2011 the area has mostly been under militant control. Al-Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack, their latest since President Hadi came to office in February.
Following mediation with tribal elders, 73 soldiers were freed on 29 April 2012 by the militants.
source_urls: Al Jazeera; AFP; Yemen Post; Reuters; Yemen online.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen attacked two military bases in Al-Mukalla, killing one soldier and wounding at least 20 others.
The attacks occurred at the entrance to the Central Security Forces base in the city. Three grenades were thrown at the main gates, before gunfire was exchanged with soldiers. A second explosion occurred an hour later, from explosives planted in the walls of the base. A third explosion occurred in the centre of the base.
The attacks came hours after an AQAPsuicide attack in the Al-Bayda province, and a week after a suicide bomb in the town killed 26 people. Although AQAPdid not comment on the attack, it is most likely responsible.

summary:
Two suspected Al-Qaeda militants drove an explosive-laden vehicle into the Dar al-Nasr Republican Guard army base in al-Bayda governorate. The explosion killed one soldier and wounded five more.
The dawn blast destroyed a three-storey building, as well as damaging houses and blowing out windows within a a two kilometre radius. In the wake of the explosion, a short gun battle ensued between soldiers and armed militants.
Al-Bayda borders the Abyan governorate, an Al-Qaeda stronghold in the country.
The attack comes a week after Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula conducted a suicide attack in Hadramawt that killed 26 Republican Guards.

summary:
A bomb blast detonated in the commercial area of Jolo, killing two people and wounding at least 13 more.
The homemade device exploded on Serrantes Street, the same area in which an Abu Sayyaf militant was shot dead the previous week by police. The device was left outside a grocery shop frequented by Philippine marines. The shop had been closed at the time of the explosion, and most of the victims had been bystanders at a nearby park.
Police believe Abu Sayyaf to be responsible, stating that they were the only ones with the capability to launch such an attack. The region has been part of the Abu Sayyaf stronghold for over ten years.
Abu Sayyaf made no comment.
source_urls: Philippine Star;Inquirer News; AFP;  ZamboTimes; AP;

summary:
Al-Shabaab affiliated militants launched two attacks against military posts near Bassaso overnight. Three civilians were wounded in the attacks.
Militants of the Golis militia, who recently announced their merger with Al-Shabaab attacked first in the early hours of the night. A second attack against a military outpost was then launched before dawn. In the ensuing fight, seven militants were killed.
Al-Shabaab claimed in a radio broadcast that the attack had killed five Puntland troops, but there was no official report of fatalities.

summary:
An Al-Qaeda faction detonated a suicide car bomb at a gendarmerie base in Tamanrasset, southern Algeria. At least 24 people were wounded in the attack.
The blast occurred at the main entrance of the headquarters of the bridge in the city. Three civilians who had been passing by, as well as security personnel, were wounded in the explosion. Buildings in the vicinity sustained heavy damage.
The attack was the first of it's kind in the city. Recent attacks have targeted the eastern regions of the country. The Tamanrasset headquarters is the site ofa joint military effort to coordinate anti-insurgency action in the Sahara desert area.
The Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa claimed responsibility for the attack. They faction had separated from Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) in order to expand their operations. The group have previously claimed responsibility for kidnapping three European aid workers in October 2011.
source_urls: Xinhua; AFP; Reuters; BBC Mon; El  Watan

Ansar al-Sharia, a self-proclaimed affiliate of AQAP claimed responsibility in a text message sent to journalists. The groupclaimed it killed a CIA operative in the operation.The shooting came a day after AQAP warned in a communiqu posted onto a jihadist forum that its operations would 'reach the American project and its tools' in the country.
The Pentagon confirmed that a US security team had come under fire, but denied there were any casualties.

summary:
Suspected terroristsdetonated a bomb near a local office of the ruling AK Party in the Stlce district of Istanbul. According to local security officials, the device was attached to a motorcycle and exploded as a police bus drove past the office. The blast wounded ten policemen.
No group claimed responsibility, but the attack came three weeks after the KCK, the umbrella organisation that controls Kurdish militancy in Turkey, issued a statement threatening a surge in attacks against administrative and security targets, including in urban centres.
It seems likely that a Kurdish militant group, most probably the Kurdistan Freedom Hawks (TAK), was behind the attack. The authorities believe the TAK is the PKK's urban wing, and have accused the KCK of directing the activities of both terrorist groups.

Media reports said the militants targeted a military convoy using mortars. Artillery and gunfire was then exchanged, resulting in the death of nine soldiers and five militants.
Al-Shabaab did not claim the attack.

summary:
Suspected Al-Shabaab militants killed a police reservist and injured another eight civilians in a connected grenade attack, in the Kenya-Somalia border town of Mandera.
Reports confirm three armed militants entered a shop and killed the police reservist, before fleeing on foot. An angry crowd pursued the assailants, capturing and killing one of them. The remaining attacker then threw a hand grenade into the crowd, injuring eight people.
Al-Shabaab has launched numerous cross-border offensives in recent months.

summary:

Details are still being confirmed, but it appears a landmine exploded near the base, causing the army to open fire. Report suggest one of the assailants was killed and a nearby civilian may have also been wounded.
No group have claimed responsibility for the attack, but the likelihood is Al-Shabaab militants are the perpetrators.

summary: Two police officers were beaten by an armed gang at an Administrative Police camp in Chanaganda, Kilifi.  Earlier intelligence reports indicated members of the outlawed Mombasa Republican Council (MRC) planned to attack the camp later that day. It is believed a gang of at least ten militants set upon the officers, causing serious injuries.  As a result of police operations 15 men have already been arrested.  The MRC are a secession group, aimed at liberating the Kenyan coastal region from what they perceive as decades of marginalisation and prejudice by the government. This attack may be an indication of an increase in MRC activities.

Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the attack, the the third in five days in the north-west area. Asim Mehsud, a TTP spokesman, said that the ANP would continue to be targeted.

summary:
A suicide car bomb detonated at the gates of Jalabad airport. The explosion killed nine people and wounded at least ten more.
Just after dawn, a car pulled up at the gates, and the suicide bomber detionated the bomb. Six civilians, two guards and a soldier were killed in the blast. Several cars at the entrance were also destroyed. The airport serves both civilians and military flights, though is mainly used by NATO aircraft. Four NATO soldiers were amongst the wounded.
The Taliban claimed responsibility, saying the attack was revenge for the burning of Korans at an American military base several days earlier.

summary: A bombing outside the Nepal Oil Corporation offices in Kathmandu killed three people and wounded at least six others.  The attack occurred in the centre of the city, near government offices and the district court. The blast took place as a meeting was underway within the Nepal Oil Corporation's offices, regarding the recent rise in fuel prices.  The militant group Samyukta Jatiya Mukti Morcha (SJMM) aka Unified National Liberation Front, claimed responsibility for the attack.A spokesman for SJMM said in a local TV interview that it targeted the high profile NOC building because of the government's decision to increase fuel prices.

summary: A home-made bomb was discovered on a metro strain at Egaleo station in Athens, causing the closure of the station and an evacuation of all commuters. Bomb disposal police defused the device by a controlled explosion.  The device was set to detonate by timer, and was found beneath a seat on the carriage by the train driver. The train had stopped at the station and no passengers were aboard at the time. It had been en route to Athens Airport.  The bomb comprised two gas canisters and 1.5 litres of gasoline, and had been packaged inside a gift box. Police reported that the timer had been activated and completed its countdown, but the device had failed to explode.  Two days after the explosion, an unknown group called Antartiko Poleon (Urban Guerrilla) claimed responsibility. Police were unsure whether the claim was a hoax - the group was hitherto unheard of. On 1 April, the "February 12th Movement" posted a claim of responsibility online in a seven-page letter. Police believe this claim is genuine.  The 12 February date refers to arson attacks in Athens during an anti-austerity protest.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name:  Far-Left/Anarchist (undetermined), perpetrator_type: Far Left/Revolutionary,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

The explosion occurred in the residential neighbourhood when the device accidentally detonated as militants were planting it. A passer-by was wounded in the attack, along with the two militants. This was the third attack in Peshawar within two days. No group claimed responsibility.

summary:
Terrorists launched a suicide attack against a police station in the Lahore Gate area of Peshawar, killing four policemen and wounding six.
The militants, wearing suicide jackets and armed with guns and grenades, concealed themselves within the police station first thing in the morning, before open fire and throwing hand grenades at police within the building. It sparked a two hour gunfight between the militants and police, before the suicide vests were finally detonated.
The Abdulla Azzam Brigade claimed responsibility for the attack, citing revenge for drone strikes that killed a commander as the motive, and warning that more attacks would be planned. It was the second attack within two days in Peshawar.

summary:
Unidentified assailant detonated a roadside bombnear to a school and a mosque in Al Taji. The explosion injured five people.
The attack was part of wave of co-ordinated shootings and bombings which took place across Iraq. The attacks began at around 0600hrs and killed at least 50 people and wounded more than 200 others over a two and a half hour period in Baghdad, Mosul, Salahuddin and Kirkuk. The attacks predominantly targeted security forces but also killed many civilians.
The Islamic State of Iraq, a branch of Al-Qaeda, claimed responsibility for the attack, citing it as revenge for actions taken against Sunnis around the country.

The attacks began at around 0600hrs and killed at least 50 people and wounded more than 200 others over a two and a half hour period in Baghdad, Mosul, Salahuddin and Kirkuk. The attacks predominantly targeted the Iraqi police force and Shia civilians.
The Islamic State of Iraq, a branch of Al-Qaeda, claimed responsibility for the attack, citing it as revenge for actions taken against Sunnis around the country.

summary:
Suspected Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) planted two bombs in San Vicente del Caguan, ahead of a cabinet meeting chaired by President Santos. The devices were disarmed before they could detonate.
A controlled explosion was carried out on a 25kg cylinder filled with shrapnel and explosives. The device had been concealed in the centre of the town, close to residential buildings. Three hours later, a second controlled explosion was carried out on a dustbin containing 10 sticks of pentolite explosive and shrapnel.
The presidential meeting was scheduled to occur in the location of the 1998-2002 demilitarized zone. The meeting was part of the 10th anniversary of the failed peace process.
FARC made no comment on the incident, thought to haven been carried out by the Teofilo Forero branch.
source_urls: El Pais; Presensa Latina; Caracol Radio;

summary:
A bomb blast killed at least eight militia members at a checkpoint in the Tirah Valley, Khyber Agency. Six more were wounded in the explosion.
The Stana security checkpoint at Nari Baba was being manned by an anti-Taliban militia forces when a remote-controlled device remotely detonated. In the wake of the explosion, militiamen went to retrieve the bodies of the dead, and militants opened fire. Two militants were killed in the exchange of fire.
Militias have been frequent targets for militants, as they are perceived as supporters of the government. This particular militia was established to combat the Lashkar-e-Islam (LeI) group, which has similarities though no formal like to the Pakistan Taliban.
No responsibility was claimed, but the authorities blamed LeI.

The attackers had written to the prison several times in the days before the attack to demand the release of its members. Other sources said Boko Haram was behind the attack. In 2011, Boko Haram conducted at least 30 bank robberies across Nigeria.

summary:
An Iranian manwas responsible for three explosions in Bangkok. Two of the blasts occurred in the residential area of Sukhumvit Soi 71, while a third took place in Pridi Bhanomyong Soi 31.
Accounts of the incidents are inconsistent, but police believed the man blew up his rented home, and then threw a grenade at a taxi on Sukhumvit Soi 71 after the driver refused to pick him up. The explosion injured the driver and three local nationals. As the man fled, he hurled a second bomb at police, which rebounded off a tree and caused him severe injuries.
According to an official statement, police searched for two other foreigners with whom the bomber rented his house in Pridi Bhanomyong Soi 31, and who fled the scene of the first explosion before police arrived.
The explosions came a day after the Israeli government blamed Iran for an attack on a diplomatic vehicle in Delhi, and an attempted attack on a local staff member of the Israeli Embassy in Tbilisi, Georgia. These attacks were against Israeli diplomatic targets.
Last month, more than a dozen foreign governments issued warnings of a threat of terrorist attacks in the Thai capital following the discovery of an alleged Hezbollah plot against Israeli and Jewish targets, and the arrest of an alleged Lebanese member of the group.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks.
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Civilians/General Public

summary:
A double suicide bomb attack in Aleppo killed 28 people and injuring over 175 others. State television reports said a car bomb exploded near a military security building while another detonated at the barracks of the Security Preservation forces. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a London based activist group, reported explosions in the Sakhur and Marjeh neighbourhoods and at the Dawer al-Basel Roundabout.
Shortly after the incident, an apparent member of the rebel Free Syria Army (FSA), claimed responsibility on behalf of the group. An FSA spokesperson based in Turkey contradicted the man's statement and denied that the FSA was involved in the bombings. He claimed that the Assad regime staged the attacks as a pretext' to send troops into Aleppo.
The Syrian government said terrorists were responsible. In a 45 minute video posted on 26 February, the al-Nusra Front claimed responsibility for the attack. They cited the attack as revenge for the government's siege of Homs. A second video was released on 25 April, depicting the attack and containing messages from the two bombers involved.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jabhat al-Nusra (JaN/Al-Nusra Front), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) rebels attempted to bomb a telecommunications tower and bridge in Caloto, Cauca department, but were intercepted by the army. Two civilians were injured in the clash.
Rebels had been attempting to detonate 'tatuco' homemade bombs when they were intercepted by the military, sparking a gunfight and spate of explosions that lasted all day between the two sides. Five militants were killed and another injured in the clash, and two civilians in the vicinity were injured by the explosions. Many homes in the town sustained material damage.
FARC have been escalating their attacks in recent weeks, and negotiations for the proposed release of six hostages have faltered.

No responsibility was claimed. There have been fears of increased insecurity within Kenya after Kenyan Defence Force personnel were deployed into Somalia in order to deal with the Al-Shabaab threat.

summary:

The two women were part of a group of five tourists travelling to Sharm el-Sheikh when their minibus was stopped by armed men near the site of the monastery.
Security in the tourist region has decreased since the rebellion that overthrew former President Mubarak a year ago.
The Sinai Security Chief later reported the same day that the two tourists had been released, though the kidnappers demands for the release of relatives held prisoner had not appeared to have been met.

summary:

Tehrik-i-Taliban militants claimed responsibility for the attack, citing revenge for the killing of a commander in the Khyber Agency. It was the second attack in Kurram within a week.

The intended target of the blast, the property owner, was also the leader of a banned militant group. 30 - 40 kg of explosives were used in the attack.

summary: Rebels attacked a Chinese construction company camp, kidnapping 29 Chinese nationals from South Kurdufan state. Nine members of the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) were also seized in the attack.  The Chinese nationals had principally been involved in road construction work in the oil-rich area. The locality has been the site of fighting between the government and rebels allied to the newly-independent South Sudan state. There were no reports of wounded or fatalities.  The hostages were captured after the Sudan People's Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N) attacked and destroyed a military convoy en route between Rashad and Al-Abbasiya in the northeast of the province. The SPLM-N confirmed that they had taken the hostages.

summary:
Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of a German engineer from Kano, and demanded the release of a German Muslim woman in exchange for the engineer.
AQIM posted a video on jihadi websites of the man, who identified himself and asked the German government to help him. It is the first confirmed, direct tie of AQIM to terrorist activities within Nigeria. The engineer was seized on the Kano-Zaria motorway, from the site of the Dantata and Sawoe construction company for whome he was working.
The German woman in question was the wife of one of the 'Sauerland bombers' who attempted to attack American targets within Germany.
On 31 May it was reported that the engineer had been killed before Joint Task Force (JTF) officers were able to rescue him. The JTF had traced his location to the Danbare area, and were conducting a raid when the kidnappers shot dead their hostage. Seven Boko Haram militants were reported to have been killed in the conduct of the raid.
source_urls: Reuters; BBC News; AFP; Washington Post; All Africa; vanguard

summary:
An improvised explosive device (IED) detonated in the mostly Christian Sabon Gari area of Kano. Two people were wounded in the blast.
The IED detonated between two buses parked at the motor park on the New Road. The device had been fashioned into a soft drinks can that was thrown between the buses, causing glass to shatter. Soldiers searched the area, and there were unconfirmed reports that a utility vehicle had been found laden with explosives.
The Sabon Gari area is mostly inhabited by non-native people. Boko Haram have carried out a spree of attacks in Kano within the week, which have killed over 170 people. No claim of responsibility was made for the latest attack.
source_urls: All Africa; The Nation Online NG.net; Vanguard

summary:
Two explosions targeted churches in the north eastern town of Bauchi. There were no reported casualties, but the attacks were the latest in a wave to hit the country over the weekend.
One explosion at a church by the railway line, caused damage to the front gate. A second near IBB Square in Jahun completely destroyed the building. The attacks occurred in the early hours of the morning, when the churches were empty.
Boko Haram were blamed for the explosions, which came in the wake of a spree of attacks in the north during the weekend that left over 150 people dead.

summary:
A Boko Haram attack in Tafawa Balewa, Bauchi state, killed nine people and 12 more were wounded.
The attack targeted both the local police station, as well as private homes. Home-made grenades were thrown into houses as people slept. Gunmen then opened fire on people who attempted to flee the buildings. One police officer and a soldier were also killed in the attacks. Five militants were killed in the return fire by police.
Sectarian violence has been increasing since the Christmas period, as Boko Haram have targeted Christians in the country. Tafawa Balewa is located in the middle ground that divides Nigeria's Muslim north from Christian south.

summary:
Al-Qaeda militants attacked the house of a witchdoctor in central Rada'a, killing three people and wounding several others.
Militants used machine guns and mortal shells to attack a house in the centre of the town, sparking a firefight with residents. One militant was killed in the exchange of fire.
The attack occurred in the failure of a third round of tribal mediation that had been taking place after militants seized control of the town. One of the demands had been for the release of several militant prisoners.
Rada'a is located by a key motorway that connects the capital Sana'a with the south of the country. Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) have been exploiting the internal instability in the wake of uprisings against the country's President Salah. They had managed to seize control of several areas across the south and east of the country.

summary:
50 Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) guerrillas ambushed a police patrol in the Garwah district of Jharkhand, killed 13 policemen and wounded two more.
The patrol were initially wounded by a landmine explosion. A second blast occurred as survivors evacuated the vehicle, before the Maoists opened fire on the survivors. Two of the dead policemen were thrown back into the burning vehicle after the ambush. The Maoists also looted weapons from the ambushed patrol. The force of the explosion reportedly threw the vehicle 30 feet into the air, suggesting over 50 kg of explosives must have been involved.
The patrol had been accompanying a local government official. Although the official's vehicle was not targeted, she and her guards were missing in the wake of the attack.
The Maoists claimed responsibility for the attack, stating it was a protest against anti-Maoist police action.
source_urls: Zee News; BBC Monitoring; PTI News Agency; IBN Live;

summary:
FARC guerrillas attacked an aviation radar station, killing one, wounding three and destroying equipment in Cauca department.
100 militants used homemade missiles to attack the installation on the Cerro Santana mountain-top. One security guard was killed in the attack which lasted over 12 hours. Army aircraft were eventually able to repel the attack.
The radar was used both for civil aviation, and also the help authorities monitor drug traffic in the area. Both internal and external flights from Cali city would be affected by the damage to the equipment.
Despite the reduction in strength in recent months, the attack demonstrated the continued ability of the group to disrupt the national economy and infrastructure.

summary:
Boko Haram carried out a series of coordinated bomb and gun attacks on at least eight locations in Kano, killing at least 178 people.
The wave of explosions and gunfire occurred after Friday prayers, and targeted four police stations, the headquarters of the State Security Service (SSS), two immigration centres and passport offices in the city. In the eastern district of Bompai, a shootout occurred at the state police headquarters. The SSS headquarters were located in a popular expat neighbourhood, and foreign nationals are believed to be among the dead. A convoy of motorcycles led by a car patrolled the streets, shooting indiscriminately. Witnesses reported some of the drivers to be no older than teenagers.
At least three of the explosions were the work of suicide bombers, including an attack on a police station in the Marhaba district, when an explosive-laden car was driven into the building. Police reported that the terrorists wore police uniforms to disguise themselves.
An overnight curfew was maintained within the city, and fatality numbers were expected to rise as the hospitals were not equipped to deal with the high levels of casualties. The number of casualties make it the largest attack carried out by the group.
Boko Haram claimed responsibility, and stated that the attacks were reprisals for failure by the authorities to release members who had been arrested in the city.
source_urls: BBC; CNN; Reuters Africa; IOL News.za; Russia Today; RTE;

summary:

Homes and businesses, including a residential care home were evacuated before the explosions occurred. Dissident republicans have been blamed for the attack, but no group claimed responsibility. Londonderry is due to become the UK City of Culture in 2013.

summary:
Yemeni media sources said Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) killed three Yemeni soldiers and kidnapped seven others in the town of Radda.
AQAP seized control of Radaa, a town 130km south of the Yemeni capital, Sanaa on 14th January. The takeover is the group's most northern advance since it began capturing territory in the country's south last May.
According to reports, over 250 heavily armed militants stormed the town in Al-Baya province.  Facing little resistance, gunmen stole weapons from police stations and freed over 200 prisoners. A number of inmates, suspected of being AQAP members, reportedly joined the militants.

summary:
Abidah tribesman kidnapped a Norwegian UN worker from Sanaa and transported him to the Marib province.
The armed tribesmen seized the worker from the capital city, before driving to the Marib province. They demanded the release of a fellow tribesman in exchange for the aid worker.
The aid worker, an expert from the UN Development Programme (UNDP), was seized south of the neighbourhood site of the presidential palace, one of the busiest and supposedly most secure neighbourhoods of the city.
Tribesmen frequently seize hostages to force negotiations with the government. Two months earlier, a French aid worker was seized along with her driver and translator in the south of the country, but released unharmed two days later.

summary:

summary:
Three explosions took place near the Jalan Duta court complex in Kuala Lumpur.Police initially attributed the series of explosions to firecrackers but later blamed homemade bombs for blasts, which they say injured at least five people. The bombs were reportedly packed with ball bearings.The explosions came after the conclusion of the trial of the former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.
The first detonated at 1020hrs beneath a police cone outside the court house. Two people including a lawyer were injured by the blast. The second 25 minutes later and 100 metres from the first had been concealed near a food cart and wounded a three people in the vicinity as well as damaging a drinks van and two motorbikes. The third, 35 minutes after the first, occurred near Gate B of the courthouse, and was also concealed beneath a police cone. No casualties were incurred in the last blast, though four cars were damaged.
After the explosions, police dispersed the estimated 4,500 people gathered at the pro-Anwar rally. Subsequent searches around the bomb sites discovered no further explosives
No group or individual claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary:
Unidentified militants kidnapped a British doctor working for the International Red Cross (ICRC) in Quetta.
The Yemen-born aidworker was seized as he returned home, in the Chaman Housing Scheme area of Quetta. It was a high security location, and the location for several international organisations including the UN. The aidworker had been in the city nearly a year.
The International Red Cross closed six offices in response to the kidnapping amid further security concerns.
Three months later on 29 April, the aidworker's beheaded body was dumped on a roadside in Quetta. Both head and body had been left in separate plastic bags with his name written on the bags. A note attached claimed he had been killed because a ransom had not been paid.
No group claimed responsibilty for the kidnapping.

summary:
A grenade attack killed two people and wounded two more in Mabusao, Capiz state.
The grenade was thrown by unidentified men at a house as the residents slept. There was no apparent motive for the attack.
No group claimed responsibility.
area: Libo-on village, Mabusao,Capiz state, Western Visayas region

summary:
Unidentified gunmen shot dead a refugee leader of the Ifo Dadaab camp in north-eastern Somalia.
The victim had been a member of the Lutheran World Federation [LWF] peace committee, and was shot at close range in his hotel room on Sunday night.
Al-Shabaab sympathisers are thought to have carried out the attack before escaping to the Kenyan-Somali border. There has been an increase in attacks in the past two months relating to the Ifo camp, targeting security provision. It is the second shooting at the camp within a week.
source_urls: Xinhua; The Standard Kenya; Capital FM Kenya;
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A landmine blast in the Sui area of Balochistan killed three Frontier Corps [FC] troops and wounded two more.
The FC troops have been on patrol when their vehicle struck the concealed landmine, generating the blast.
The Baloch Republican Army claimed responsibility for the attack.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Daily Times; The Express Tribune; Dawn.com
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Balochistan Republic Army, perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Two bombs were defused from a forest road in the Awapalli area if Bijapur shortly before a police convoy was due to pass by.
Maoist insurgents were suspected of having planted the 40kg bombs on the site. They have run a parallel administration in the area since the 1980s.
area: Awapalli area, Bijapur district, Baster region, Chhattisgarh

summary:
Two suicide bombers in an explosive-laden car were detained in the Shamir area of Maywand district, before they could carry out their attack.
Afghan National Army troops stopped the car during routine checks. The vehicle was removed and safely detonated. No further details were available, but car bombs are a frequent tactic employed by the Taliban in order to further instability within the country. Kandahar was previously a Taliban stronghold. It follows in the wake of an explosive-laden vehicle that was also discovered and defused two days prior in neighbouring Helmand province.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Afghan Islamic Press; Xinhua;
area: Shamir area, Maywand district, Kandahar province
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

specific_target: Vice President of the Awami National Party
summary:
According to News International, unidentified attackers ambushed the vice president of the Awami National Party as he travelled through Khwajarhi village. Gunmen reportedly fired on the political figure when he got out of his car. The man's body guards fired back and a 30 minute firefight reportedly took place.
No group claimed the assassination attempt.
area: Hameedi Road, Khwajarhi village, Bannu, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa
author: Unknown author
